bibl.title: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, April 1, 1900

div1.p: Louise Kean mentions a mutiny on the Sedgewick and a reception for Senators at the governor's palace. Either Jefferson Randolph Kean or Gorgas will be named Chief Surgeon of the Department.

div1.head: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, April 1, 1900
div1.p:
We are all wait-
ing anxiously to hear
from you, so that we
can know what the
mutiny on the Sedge-
wick amounted to-
Helen's cable to Caz came
just after we had
seen the newspaper
accounts, and we were
very much entertained
at her description of
your voyage as “calm”-
I am counting on a
letter tomorrow or Tues-
day.

Since I last wrote you
I don't think I have
been anywhere, Martha
and Rannie have done
the gadding for the
family. Martha lunched
at the Jordans yester-
day, and I am told
behaved beautifully.
When I went for her
she seemed at peace
with both the little
Jordans and very
happy, so I think her
first day away from her family was
a success.

Thursday there was a review of
the troops for Senators Butler and
Teller, and a small reception at
the palace afterwards. I never saw
such hay - seeds as the Senators and
their wives their grammar was queer
and their clothes queerer, and now,
when we all thought the entertain-
of celebreties was over, it is said Gen. and
Mrs. Miles are on their way here!

We hear the fateful order from
Washington consolidating everything
will be here this week. In the
meantime Dr. Carter is ordered
to Willetts' Point and poor Dr. De
Witt is ordered by Gen. Wood to
take a long sick leave, you know
he was threatened with a stroke
of paralysis. So whe hear, Dr. Howard
is to come from San-
tiago to be Chief Surgeon
of the Division, and
that leaves Rannie and
Dr. Gorgas, one for
Chief Surgeon of the Dept.
and one for Sanitary
Officer, but which for
which we know not.
Tho' Gen. Ludlow is go-
ing away he seems to
be still trying to get
Rannie into the later
position. Did you see
the Widow in Town
Topics on the subject
of Gen. Ludlow. I cannot
see anything clever in
them her remarks, they seem to
me just spiteful.

Dr. Reed left yester-
day, vowing that Rannie
was “the coming man”
and that he would
see to it that “George
Miller” (the S. G.) ordered
him on for the meeting
of the Military Surgeons,
and that when Geo.
Miller was safely off
for Paris he and Rannie
would go off on a “toot”
all over the States-

Who do you think Rannie saw
on the wharf leaving on the same
Tampa boat? Mr. and Mrs. F. I. Brown.
They came to Havana one day and
left the next.

Has Art gotten my nainsook yet?
Be sure and write me how much
it is, for I did not keep a copy of
the list we made, and so I have
really forgotten how much I ordered.
My pink dress is very nearly finished
and it is very pretty.

I hope Caz will come out and dine
with us tonight, for I have not seen
him since you left. Martha
wrote you a long letter this morn-
ing, put it in an envelope and
gave it to her father to mail, and
she insists it is very unnecessary for
me to write too. With a great deal
of love
